wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the BigMatch system. Explain its purpose as a full-stack sports event management platform enabling users to create and manage tournaments, handle team registrations, track matches in real-time, and maintain rankings. Describe the high-level architecture including frontend (Next.js App Router), backend API routes, authentication via Better Auth, database with Prisma and PostgreSQL, and real-time features. Illustrate the main user roles (Organizer, Team, Player) and their workflows. Include diagrams showing system context and user interactions. Document key entry points such as homepage, dashboard, event pages, and live match viewing. Provide a conceptual overview suitable for beginners while including technical depth for developers, covering deployment setup, configuration, and extensibility points.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Endpoints
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the BigMatch RESTful API endpoints. Document HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE), URL patterns, request/query/body parameters, and response schemas for each endpoint group: Events, Matches, Rankings, Draws, Inscriptions, User Roles, and Authentication. Specify authentication requirements (e.g., Bearer token, session cookie) and role-based access control per endpoint. Include examples of successful and error responses with status codes. Explain real-time capabilities where applicable (e.g., live match updates). Address rate limiting, input validation, and error handling strategies. Provide usage examples from actual frontend integrations using src/lib/api.ts. Document versioning considerations and backward compatibility policies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the BigMatch component architecture. Explain the modular, feature-based organization of UI components across the components/ directory. Describe the role and implementation of key component categories: authentication guards (DashboardGuard, RoleGuard), dashboard widgets (EventCard, StatsGrid), event management forms (CreateEventHeader, EventRules), and match interaction components (MatchTimer, ScoreBoard). Document the use of compound components and component composition patterns. Include examples of how components are reused across different pages such as /dashboard, /events/[id], and /matches/[id]. Explain the export patterns using index.ts files for clean imports. Address accessibility features implemented via Radix UI primitives in components/ui/ and how they integrate with custom components. Provide guidance on extending existing components and creating new ones following project conventions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication & Authorization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Authentication & Authorization system. Explain the implementation of Better Auth with Google OAuth integration, secure session management using HTTP-only cookies, and role-based access control. Document the API routes for authentication and user role handling, including token flow and session validation. Describe the frontend guard components (ProtectedRoute, RoleGuard) and their integration with custom React hooks. Include examples of role enforcement for Organizer, Team, and Player roles. Explain how user roles are stored and validated across requests. Address common issues such as session expiration, role escalation prevention, and secure cookie handling. Provide code examples from actual implementation and detail the interaction between client and server layers.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the User entity in the BigMatch application. Detail all fields including id, email, name, image, and createdAt, specifying their data types, constraints, and default values. Explain the relationship between User and UserRole through the userRoles relation field, and how it supports multiple roles per user. Document the primary key configuration, unique constraints on email, and indexing strategies for query performance. Describe how user data is accessed and manipulated via Prisma Client in src/lib/prisma.ts. Include examples of common queries such as fetching a user with their roles, and explain any business rules or validation logic enforced at the schema level.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Authentication Flow. Explain the implementation of Better Auth with Google OAuth integration, including the authentication middleware and session management. Document the secure handling of user sessions using HTTP-only cookies and the interaction between client and server layers. Describe the authentication API routes and their role in session creation, validation, and destruction. Include examples of successful and failed authentication scenarios, token handling, and session persistence. Address common issues such as OAuth callback configuration, session fixation prevention, and cross-origin request handling. Provide code examples from the actual implementation and explain security considerations for production deployment.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the Authentication API endpoints in BigMatch. Document all routes under app/api/auth/[...all]/route.ts, including sign-in, sign-out, session management, and user role verification. Specify HTTP methods, request/response formats, authentication mechanisms (Better Auth with Google OAuth), and security headers. Include detailed examples of successful and error responses (401, 403, etc.). Explain how the API integrates with frontend components like ProtectedRoute and hooks like useSecureUserRole. Provide curl and fetch code samples for each operation. Address common issues such as token expiration, CSRF protection, and session persistence across domains. Document the role-based access control flow and how user roles are validated server-side.

wiki_catalogs.name: Championship Format
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Championship Format (league system). Explain how round-robin scheduling works, including full and partial league configurations. Document the point system configuration (win/draw/loss) and its impact on ranking calculations. Describe the playoff phase implementation, including qualification rules and bracket generation for top teams. Detail the UI component ChampionnatRules.tsx that allows organizers to configure these settings. Include examples of team pairing algorithms and match generation logic from tournament.ts. Address edge cases such as odd team counts requiring byes and scheduling conflicts. Explain integration with the ranking system for automatic standings updates after each match.

wiki_catalogs.name: Event Creation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Event Creation feature. Explain the step-by-step UI flow in the create-event form, including field validation, dynamic rule rendering (Championship vs. Cup), and submission handling. Document the relationship between frontend components and the underlying Event interface. Describe how form data maps to the Prisma schema fields, including optional constraints like maxTeams and isPrivate. Provide code examples showing form state management and error handling. Illustrate how the registrationCode is generated and used for team sign-ups. Address common issues such as incomplete form submission, invalid date/time entries, and duplicate event names. Include best practices for ensuring data consistency and user guidance during creation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Ranking Calculation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the ranking calculation system. Explain the algorithm used to compute team standings in championship-style tournaments, including point allocation for wins, draws, and losses. Document the tie-breaking logic implemented in src/utils/ranking.ts and how it handles edge cases like equal points. Describe the data structure of the Ranking interface in src/types/ranking.ts. Detail how match results trigger automatic recalculation via the API endpoint at app/api/rankings/[eventId]/route.ts. Include code examples showing the calculation pipeline from match update to ranking persistence. Address performance considerations for large events and potential optimizations such as batch processing or caching strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Match Lifecycle Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Match Lifecycle Management. Explain the complete lifecycle of a match from creation to completion, including draft, scheduled, in-progress, and completed states. Document the API endpoints responsible for match creation (both scheduled and standalone) and state transitions. Describe how match data is validated upon creation using src/types/match.ts interfaces and business rules enforced in src/utils/match.ts. Detail the relationship between matches and events, including how matches are associated with specific events and teams. Provide examples of creating matches via both the organizer dashboard and API calls. Address error handling for invalid match configurations and edge cases such as duplicate matches or invalid team pairings. Discuss how match creation triggers downstream effects like ranking recalculations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Role Data Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the UserRole entity. Detail the structure of the UserRole object including all fields (id, userId, roleType, isActive, createdAt, updatedAt) and the nested user object with its properties. Explain the RoleType enumeration values (Organizer, Team, Player) and their significance in the application. Document the data types, constraints, and business rules such as the requirement for exactly one active role per user. Include information about how the role data is synchronized between the database, HTTP-only cookies, and client state. Provide examples of UserRole objects from both API responses and client-side representations. Address data validation rules and integrity constraints enforced by the system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the BigMatch technology stack. Detail each core technology: Next.js 15 with React 19 for full-stack rendering, TypeScript for type safety, Prisma ORM for database access, Better Auth for authentication, Tailwind CSS for styling, React Query for data fetching, Radix UI for accessible components, and PostgreSQL as the database. For each technology, explain its role in the system, version compatibility, configuration approach, and integration pattern with other components. Include code examples showing how these technologies are initialized and used in the codebase. Address why these technologies were chosen and their benefits for the application's scalability and developer experience. Provide links to official documentation and best practices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BigMatch authentication and authorization system. Explain the integration of Better Auth with Google OAuth, including token exchange, session management, and secure cookie handling via secure-cookies.ts. Document the authentication flow from frontend login to backend session creation and validation. Describe the role-based access control mechanism using UserRole and how it's enforced in API routes and protected components. Include sequence diagrams showing login, session validation, and role checking flows. Cover security practices such as JWT signing, cookie security flags, and CSRF protection. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common authentication issues like expired sessions or role mismatches.

wiki_catalogs.name: Routing & Navigation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the Next.js App Router routing system in BigMatch. Detail the file-based routing structure and dynamic route segments like [id], [eventId], and [token]. Explain the layout hierarchy using layout.tsx and nested route groups such as dashboard and events. Document the navigation patterns between key user flows: event creation, match management, live viewing, and dashboard access. Describe how route parameters are extracted and used in page components. Include examples of client-side navigation using Next.js Link and router.push. Explain the integration between routing and authentication via ProtectedRoute and RoleGuard components. Cover error handling for invalid routes and the 404 behavior. Provide best practices for adding new routes while maintaining security and role-based access.

wiki_catalogs.name: Event Management System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Event Management System. Thoroughly explain the event lifecycle (draft → published → registration_open → in_progress → completed), including status transitions and business rules. Document CRUD operations via API endpoints and their validation logic. Describe the event creation UI flow and form structure. Explain privacy settings (public/private) and search/filtering capabilities. Detail the relationship between events and other entities like matches, teams, and rankings. Include usage examples for creating, updating, and publishing events. Address common issues such as invalid state transitions, permission errors, and data consistency. Provide insights into the Prisma schema design for events and how it supports the application logic.

wiki_catalogs.name: Event Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Event entity. Detail fields such as id, name, description, startDate, endDate, location, status (with enum values: DRAFT, PUBLISHED, REGISTRATION_OPEN, IN_PROGRESS, COMPLETED), and privacy settings (PUBLIC, PRIVATE). Explain the relationships with Match, Team, Ranking, and User through respective relation fields. Document foreign key constraints, indexes on status and dates for filtering, and cascading delete behaviors. Describe how event status transitions are managed and enforced. Include migration details that evolved the schema, such as adding privacy settings and updating status enums. Provide examples of querying events by status, date ranges, or organizer roles using Prisma Client.

wiki_catalogs.name: Role Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Role Management system. Explain how user roles (Organizer, Team, Player) are created, stored, and validated across the application. Document the API endpoints for role creation, retrieval, and modification, including the secure role migration from localStorage to HTTP-only cookies. Describe the hybrid role retrieval strategy that combines server-side and client-side role persistence. Include examples of role assignment workflows and the data structure of the UserRole object. Address common issues such as role synchronization between client and server, handling of inactive roles, and prevention of role escalation attacks. Provide code examples from the useSecureUserRole and useHybridUserRole hooks and explain the caching mechanism for role data.

wiki_catalogs.name: Events API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed API documentation for the Events API in BigMatch. Cover all endpoints including event creation (POST), retrieval (GET /events, /events/all, /events/search), individual event access (GET /events/[id]), and status updates. Document request body schema for event creation, including fields like name, type (championship/cup), privacy, dates, and location. Specify query parameters for search and filtering. Detail response structures with examples for single and list responses. Explain how the API interacts with frontend hooks like useEvents and useEvent. Include error cases such as invalid event IDs or unauthorized access. Provide usage examples using fetch and curl. Address event lifecycle transitions and how status changes are handled via API.

wiki_catalogs.name: Cup Format
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Cup Format (knockout system). Explain single and double elimination mechanics, including bracket structures and progression rules. Document the group stage configuration options (number of groups and size) and advancement criteria to knockout rounds. Describe the final match types (single vs. two-leg) and third-place playoff implementation. Detail the UI component CoupeRules.tsx that enables organizers to set up these tournament parameters. Include implementation details from tournament.ts for bracket generation, team seeding, and match scheduling. Address edge cases like handling byes in unbalanced brackets and reseeding after rounds. Explain how match results propagate through the bracket and affect subsequent rounds.

wiki_catalogs.name: Event Status Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Event Status Management. Explain the finite state machine governing event status transitions: draft → published → registration_open → in_progress → completed. Document the API endpoint logic in status/route.ts that enforces valid transitions and updates timestamps. Describe UI components that reflect current status and available actions (e.g., publish, open registration). Detail business rules such as preventing status rollback or match creation before in_progress state. Provide examples of valid and invalid transition attempts. Address common issues like race conditions during status updates, unauthorized state changes, and synchronization with related entities (matches, rankings). Include debugging strategies and logging recommendations for tracking status changes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Statistics Visualization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the statistics visualization components. Describe the purpose and usage of EventStats, StatsCard, and StatsGrid components in displaying tournament performance metrics. Document their props, styling mechanisms via Tailwind CSS, and integration with data from the rankings API. Provide examples of how these components render key statistics such as match counts, win rates, and goal differentials. Explain responsive design considerations and accessibility features implemented. Illustrate how these components are composed within dashboards to present meaningful insights. Include guidance on customizing visualizations for different tournament formats or user roles.

wiki_catalogs.name: Scoring System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Scoring System. Explain how real-time score updates are handled through the PATCH /api/matches/[id]/score endpoint, including request validation and state persistence. Document the ScoreBoard component's role in displaying and submitting scores, including its integration with React state and API calls. Describe the business logic in src/utils/match.ts that validates score changes, prevents invalid inputs (e.g., negative scores), and enforces game rules. Detail how score updates trigger automatic match completion based on predefined win conditions. Provide examples of typical scoring workflows, including normal play, tie scenarios, and manual score adjustments by organizers. Address concurrency issues during simultaneous score updates and explain the error handling and rollback mechanisms in place.

wiki_catalogs.name: Role Persistence Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the role persistence mechanism. Explain the secure storage strategy that uses HTTP-only cookies via server-side API endpoints at /api/auth/user-role. Document the migration process from localStorage to secure cookies, including the automatic upgrade path for existing users. Describe the implementation of the UserRoleCookieService and its client/server methods for role management. Cover the security benefits of using HTTP-only cookies to prevent XSS attacks and protect role information. Include examples of the API contract for role storage and retrieval, and explain the fallback mechanisms when secure storage is unavailable. Address common issues such as cookie blocking, cross-origin restrictions, and browser compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Directory Structure Breakdown
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the BigMatch directory structure. Explain the purpose and contents of each top-level directory: app/ for Next.js App Router pages and API routes, components/ for reusable UI components organized by feature, lib/ for shared utilities and API clients, prisma/ for database schema and migrations, scripts/ for database setup tools, and src/ for core logic, hooks, types, and utilities. Describe the organization principles within each directory, such as feature-based grouping and separation of concerns. Highlight key files and their roles in the system. Use the project structure tree to illustrate the hierarchy. Explain how this structure supports maintainability, scalability, and developer onboarding. Provide guidance on where to add new features or modify existing ones.

wiki_catalogs.name: Business Logic Layer
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the BigMatch business logic layer. Describe how domain-specific logic for tournaments, rankings, and matches is encapsulated in utility modules under src/utils/. Explain the service layer pattern implemented in src/lib/api.ts that abstracts API interactions for the frontend. Document the use of server actions (e.g., sign-in) and their integration with the frontend. Detail the algorithms for tournament bracket generation, ranking calculations, and match state transitions. Include examples of how business rules are enforced (e.g., match auto-completion, event status progression). Address error handling, data validation, and transaction management. Explain how this layer mediates between the API routes and the data access layer (Prisma).

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create in-depth documentation for the state management strategy in BigMatch using React Query via custom hooks. Explain the design and implementation of data-fetching hooks such as useAllEvents, useEvent, and useMatches, including their integration with the API layer through src/lib/api.ts. Document the use of QueryClientProvider and server-side data fetching patterns. Describe how real-time updates are handled for match scores and timers. Explain error handling, loading states, and caching strategies implemented in the hooks. Provide examples of how components consume data from these hooks and handle mutations. Address the separation between server state (React Query) and local UI state (useState). Include performance optimization techniques like pagination, prefetching, and stale-while-revalidate patterns used in the application.

wiki_catalogs.name: Tournament Organization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Tournament Organization. Explain support for championship (league) and cup (knockout) formats, including bracket generation logic and match scheduling algorithms. Document the draw generation API endpoint and its input/output structure. Detail the utility functions in src/utils/tournament.ts that handle tournament logic, such as pairing teams and determining next rounds. Describe UI components that display tournament rules and configurations. Include examples of how draws are generated based on team registrations. Address edge cases like odd team counts, byes, and re-draws. Explain how tournament type affects match creation and ranking calculations. Provide implementation details and integration points with event and match systems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Match Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the Match entity, which represents individual games within tournaments. Document fields including id, eventId, teamAId, teamBId, scoreA, scoreB, timerState, startTime, and completed status. Explain the relationships with Event, Team (as teamA and teamB), and Ranking. Detail foreign key constraints, composite indexes for performance on eventId and timerState, and cascading updates/deletes. Describe how match outcomes automatically trigger ranking recalculations. Include the purpose of the 20250823193040_add_match_system migration that introduced this structure. Provide code examples for creating matches, updating scores, and handling real-time timer state changes via Prisma queries in src/lib/prisma.ts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Access Control
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Access Control system. Explain the implementation of role-based access control using React components such as ProtectedRoute and RoleGuard. Document how these components integrate with authentication state and user role data to enforce authorization rules. Describe the props and configuration options for each guard component, including fallback paths and role requirements. Include examples of how access control is implemented for different user roles (Organizer, Team, Player) across various pages. Address common issues such as race conditions during authentication checks, proper loading state management, and preventing unauthorized access to protected routes. Provide code examples from the actual implementation and explain best practices for implementing new access control rules.

wiki_catalogs.name: Matches API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the Matches API in BigMatch. Document endpoints for match CRUD operations, real-time score updates, timer controls (start, pause, reset, end), and standalone match creation. Specify HTTP methods, URL patterns, request body formats for score and timer actions, and expected responses. Include detailed descriptions of match state transitions and auto-completion logic. Explain how the API supports live updates and integrates with the frontend MatchControls and MatchTimer components. Provide JSON examples for match objects and state changes. Document error conditions such as invalid match states or unauthorized modifications. Include usage examples with fetch and curl, and explain how the API is consumed by useMatches and other hooks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Draw Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for Draw Management. Document the API endpoint at app/api/draws/[eventId]/route.ts that generates tournament brackets based on event configuration and team registrations. Explain the draw generation algorithm, including randomization, seeding options, and constraints for balanced matchups. Detail how draws are persisted and can be regenerated if needed. Describe the integration between the draw system and match creation, where generated draws automatically create scheduled matches. Include error handling for cases like insufficient teams or invalid configurations. Provide examples of request/response payloads for the draw generation API. Explain how organizers can trigger and review draws through the event management interface.

wiki_catalogs.name: Event Search and Filtering
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Event Search and Filtering capabilities. Explain how the /api/events/search endpoint processes queries using fuzzy matching on name, location, and type. Document the role of /api/events/all in fetching events with optional filters (status, privacy). Describe the frontend filtering UI using EventFilters.tsx and its integration with React Query via useAllEvents. Illustrate how public/private event visibility is enforced server-side. Provide usage examples for common search patterns and performance considerations for large datasets. Address common issues such as slow search response, incorrect filter application, and private event leakage. Include optimization tips like indexing strategies in PostgreSQL and client-side caching.

wiki_catalogs.name: Ranking Reset Functionality
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive content for the ranking reset feature. Explain the use case for resetting standings, such as correcting data entry errors or restarting a tournament phase. Document the API endpoint in app/api/rankings/[eventId]/route.ts that handles reset operations and its authentication requirements. Detail the implementation in src/utils/ranking.ts that clears or reinitializes ranking data while preserving historical match results. Describe the confirmation workflow using DeleteConfirmation UI component and role-based permissions required. Address data integrity safeguards, such as backup mechanisms or audit logging. Provide examples of safe reset procedures and warn against unintended data loss.

wiki_catalogs.name: Match Timer Control
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Match Timer Control. Explain the implementation of the real-time match timer with start, pause, reset, and end functionality through the /api/matches/[id]/timer endpoint. Document how the MatchTimer component displays the current time and synchronizes with backend state, including handling of timer persistence across page reloads. Describe the MatchControls component's integration with timer actions and role-based access restrictions. Detail the business logic in src/utils/match.ts that governs timer behavior, including duration limits and automatic match completion when time expires. Provide examples of timer workflows for different match types. Address synchronization challenges between client and server time, handling of concurrent timer operations, and recovery from unexpected interruptions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Client-Side Role Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for client-side role management using React hooks. Explain the implementation and use cases for both useSecureUserRole and useHybridUserRole hooks, highlighting their differences in security approach and server interaction. Document the hook interfaces, including state variables (userRole, isLoading, error) and action methods (createUserRole, changeUserRole, logout). Describe the role checking utilities (hasRole, hasAnyRole) and their usage in conditional rendering. Provide examples of integrating these hooks with RoleGuard components for route protection. Cover the caching mechanism in useHybridUserRole, including cache duration and invalidation strategies. Address common client-side issues such as role synchronization delays and handling of temporary role states.

wiki_catalogs.name: Frontend Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the BigMatch frontend architecture. Describe the high-level design using Next.js App Router with React 19, including server components, client components, and their interactions. Document the component architecture with modular, reusable components organized by feature in the components/ directory. Explain the routing system, layout structure, and navigation patterns. Cover state management using React Query through custom hooks in src/hooks/. Detail the styling strategy with Tailwind CSS and component variants. Include system context diagrams showing component hierarchy and data flow. Address cross-cutting concerns like accessibility, responsive design, and performance optimization. Explain the integration between UI components and backend APIs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Styling Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the styling architecture of BigMatch using Tailwind CSS and component-based styling. Explain the global CSS setup in globals.css and the Tailwind configuration defined in tailwind.config.ts. Describe the use of utility-first classes and how design tokens are managed through the design.json file. Detail the implementation of reusable styled components in components/ui/ using Radix UI primitives with Tailwind variants. Explain how component-specific styles are scoped and how responsive design is implemented across different views (dashboard, event pages, live match). Document the styling conventions for states (hover, active, disabled) and animations (MatchTimer, LoadingSpinner). Provide guidance on creating new components that follow the existing design system and color palette. Address accessibility considerations in color contrast and focus states.

wiki_catalogs.name: Match Operations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Match Operations. Explain real-time match functionality including score updates, timer controls (start/pause/reset/end), and auto-completion rules. Document all match-related API endpoints and their state management logic. Describe the match creation process for both scheduled and standalone matches. Detail the frontend components for score input, timer display, and control buttons. Explain how match results are validated and persisted, and how they trigger ranking updates. Include examples of typical match workflows from start to finish. Address synchronization issues, concurrent updates, and error handling during live operations. Discuss the role of src/utils/match.ts in enforcing business rules and calculating derived states.

wiki_catalogs.name: Team Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Team entity. Detail fields such as id, name, eventId, captainId, and playerIds (stored as JSON array). Explain the relationship with Event (many teams per event), User (captain and players), and its role in Match as teamA/teamB. Document constraints like team name uniqueness within an event, and referential integrity with User via captainId. Describe how team composition is validated and managed at the application level, while noting any database-level constraints. Include usage patterns such as querying all teams in an event with their players, or finding a user's team affiliations. Reference Prisma Client usage in src/lib/prisma.ts for team-related operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Rankings API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed API documentation for the Rankings API in BigMatch. Document the GET /api/rankings/[eventId] endpoint that retrieves championship standings and team statistics. Specify response schema including team ID, name, points, wins, losses, draws, goals for/against, and ranking position. Explain how rankings are automatically calculated based on match results and updated in real-time. Describe the integration with the ranking calculation utility in src/utils/ranking.ts. Include sample JSON responses for different tournament stages. Address caching behavior, data consistency, and performance considerations for large events. Provide fetch and curl examples. Explain how frontend components consume this data to display standings and statistics.

wiki_catalogs.name: Event Privacy Controls
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Event Privacy Controls. Explain the isPrivate boolean field in the Event model and its impact on event visibility and access. Document how private events require explicit invitation via registrationCode while public events appear in search results. Describe server-side enforcement in API routes to restrict access based on user role and event privacy settings. Illustrate how the frontend conditionally renders registration links and join buttons. Provide examples of creating public vs. private events and handling unauthorized access attempts. Address common issues such as accidental public exposure of private events, broken invitation flows, and permission escalation. Include security best practices for token generation and access validation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Live Match Operations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Live Match Operations. Explain the token-based access system for live match viewing at /live/[token], including token generation and security considerations. Document how the live view synchronizes real-time data (scores, timer, match status) from multiple API endpoints. Describe the MatchView component's role in presenting live match information to spectators with minimal latency. Detail the data polling strategy and state management for maintaining up-to-date information without overwhelming the server. Provide examples of the live viewing experience from both organizer and spectator perspectives. Address performance optimization techniques, error recovery during live streams, and fallback mechanisms for disconnected clients.

wiki_catalogs.name: Backend Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the BigMatch backend architecture. Describe the API design using Next.js route handlers in the app/api/ directory, following RESTful principles. Explain the service layer pattern implemented in src/lib/api.ts for abstracting API calls. Document the authentication flow using Better Auth and custom authentication logic in src/lib/auth.ts. Cover the request/response cycle, error handling, and middleware usage. Include diagrams showing API endpoint organization and data flow from frontend to database. Address security considerations, rate limiting, and API versioning strategy. Explain how the backend integrates with the frontend through React Query hooks and how it accesses the database via Prisma.

wiki_catalogs.name: Rankings & Statistics
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Rankings & Statistics. Explain automatic ranking calculation for championship-style tournaments, including points system (win/draw/loss), tie-breaking rules, and performance metrics. Document the API endpoint for retrieving rankings and its caching strategy. Detail the utility functions in src/utils/ranking.ts that implement the ranking algorithm. Describe how statistics are updated after each match result. Explain the UI components that visualize standings and performance data. Include examples of ranking tables and statistical breakdowns. Address edge cases such as incomplete tournaments, team withdrawals, and ranking resets. Discuss data persistence and performance considerations for large datasets.

wiki_catalogs.name: Ranking Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the Ranking entity responsible for storing championship standings. Detail fields including id, eventId, teamId, points, wins, losses, draws, goalsFor, goalsAgainst, and lastUpdated. Explain the one-to-many relationship between Event and Ranking, and the foreign key constraint linking to Team. Describe how rankings are automatically updated after match completions using logic in src/utils/ranking.ts. Document indexes on eventId and points for leaderboard queries, and any triggers or application-level processes that maintain data consistency. Provide examples of calculating leaderboards, handling tie-breakers, and resetting rankings for new seasons. Clarify the difference between championship and cup tournament ranking persistence.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Roles API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the User Roles API in BigMatch. Document all endpoints for managing user roles including role assignment (POST /user-roles/change), retrieving current user role (GET /user-roles/me), listing roles (GET /user-roles), and role-specific operations (GET /user-roles/[id]). Specify request/response formats, authentication requirements, and authorization checks. Explain the role hierarchy (Organizer, Team, Player) and how permissions are enforced. Detail how the API integrates with the frontend RoleGuard and DashboardGuard components. Provide examples of role change requests and responses. Address security considerations such as preventing privilege escalation and validating role changes. Include usage examples with fetch and curl, and explain integration with the user-roles utility library.

wiki_catalogs.name: Database Schema Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the BigMatch database schema. Detail all entities including User, Event, Match, Team, Ranking, and UserRole, along with their relationships, field definitions, and data types. Document primary/foreign keys, indexes, constraints, and enum types. Explain the data validation rules and business logic enforced at the database level. Include a schema diagram showing entity relationships. Describe the migration strategy using Prisma Migrate and the purpose of each migration in the prisma/migrations/ directory. Explain the seed data setup in prisma/seed.ts. Cover data access patterns, performance considerations, and transaction management through Prisma Client in src/lib/prisma.ts.

wiki_catalogs.name: UserRole Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the UserRole entity, which implements role-based access control. Detail fields including id, userId, roleId (ORGANIZER, TEAM_MANAGER, PLAYER), eventId (nullable for global vs event-specific roles), and assignedAt. Explain the composite unique index on userId, roleId, and eventId to prevent duplicate role assignments. Document the relationship with User and Event, and how it enables fine-grained permissions across multiple events. Describe the migration that introduced this model and its impact on authentication flows. Reference src/lib/user-roles.ts for role validation utilities and show examples of querying user roles for dashboard access control using Prisma Client.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on BigMatch's core features. Provide an overview of the main functionality: Authentication & Authorization, Event Management, Tournament Organization, Match Operations, and Rankings & Statistics. For each feature, explain its purpose, user workflows, and technical implementation. Document how features interact with each other and the overall system. Include high-level diagrams showing feature relationships and data flow. Address the business rules and domain logic implemented in utility functions in src/utils/. Explain how these features support different user roles and their specific needs. Provide use cases and scenarios demonstrating feature integration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Migration Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the database migration strategy using Prisma Migrate. Explain the purpose and evolution captured in each migration from 20250818112948_init to 20250823193040_add_match_system, including schema initialization, authentication improvements, event updates, privacy additions, status enum changes, and match system introduction. Describe how the migration_lock.toml ensures consistency across environments. Detail the workflow for creating new migrations during development, applying them in staging/production, and handling rollbacks. Explain how migrations are integrated into the deployment pipeline and how they interact with the Prisma Client in src/lib/prisma.ts. Provide best practices for writing reversible migrations and managing schema drift.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Flow Between Layers
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on BigMatch's data flow between layers. Explain the complete data pathway from database to UI: Database → Prisma Client → API Routes → React Query → Custom Hooks → UI Components, and vice versa for user inputs. Document how data is transformed and validated at each layer. Illustrate with sequence diagrams showing typical data operations like event creation, match scoring, and ranking calculation. Explain the role of React Query in data fetching, caching, and state synchronization. Cover real-time updates and how they are handled in the system. Address error handling, loading states, and data consistency across layers. Provide examples from the codebase showing data flow implementation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Seed Data Setup
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the database seeding process defined in prisma/seed.ts. Explain the purpose of seed data for development, testing, and onboarding demonstrations. Document the sequence of operations: creating sample users, assigning roles via UserRole, setting up test events, registering teams, generating matches, and initializing rankings. Describe how environment variables control seeding behavior and how it integrates with the database setup guide in scripts/database-setup.md. Provide instructions for running the seed script, extending it with new test scenarios, and clearing existing data. Include tips for maintaining realistic yet anonymized sample data for team names, locations, and match results.

wiki_catalogs.name: Environment Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on BigMatch environment configuration. Explain all required environment variables, their purpose, and default values, referencing the .env.local.example file mentioned in README.md. Document the configuration process for different environments (development, production). Cover database connection setup, authentication credentials, API keys, and application settings in next.config.ts. Explain how configuration is validated and loaded at runtime. Include troubleshooting guidance for common configuration issues. Provide step-by-step instructions for setting up environment variables and verifying the configuration. Address security considerations for handling sensitive configuration data.

wiki_catalogs.name: Developer Onboarding Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on onboarding new developers to the BigMatch project. Provide step-by-step instructions for setting up the development environment: cloning the repository, installing dependencies with pnpm, configuring environment variables, setting up the PostgreSQL database, and running migrations. Include commands for starting the development server, running tests, and building the application from package.json scripts. Document the database setup process using scripts/database-setup.md and seed data initialization with prisma/seed.ts. Explain the contribution workflow, code style guidelines, and testing practices. Provide troubleshooting tips for common setup issues and links to additional resources.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for all BigMatch API endpoints. For each endpoint group (auth, events, matches, rankings, user-roles), document HTTP methods, URL patterns, request/response schemas, authentication requirements, and error codes. Include detailed descriptions of parameters, query strings, request bodies, and response formats with JSON examples. Document rate limiting, versioning, and security considerations for each endpoint. Provide usage examples showing how to interact with the APIs using curl and JavaScript fetch. Explain the relationship between API endpoints and their corresponding frontend hooks. Address common integration issues and debugging strategies. Organize the documentation by functional area and include a comprehensive endpoint listing.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis of BigMatch

## 1. Project Introduction

BigMatch is a full-stack web application designed to manage sports events, tournaments, and matches. The platform enables users to create and organize events, manage team registrations, track match progress, and maintain rankings. It supports various tournament formats including championships and knockout cups, with real-time match tracking capabilities.

The core goals of BigMatch are to streamline event organization, provide real-time match management tools, and offer comprehensive tournament administration features. The application targets sports organizers, teams, players, and spectators who need a centralized platform for managing competitive events.

Target audiences include:
- Event organizers who need tools to create and manage tournaments
- Team managers and players participating in events
- Spectators who want to follow live matches and standings
- Administrators who oversee multiple events and users

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown

BigMatch follows a Next.js App Router architecture with a clear separation of concerns between frontend components, API routes, business logic, and data access layers. The application uses Prisma as an ORM for database operations and implements a modular component structure.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client] --> B[API Layer]
    B --> C[Business Logic]
    C --> D[Data Access]
    D --> E[(Database)]
    C --> F[Authentication]
    G[Prisma Client] --> E
    H[React Components] --> A
    I[Custom Hooks] --> H
```

### Design Patterns

The application implements several key design patterns:
- **Component-based architecture** using React with modular UI components
- **Role-based access control** through guard components like ProtectedRoute, RoleGuard, and EventGuard
- **Data fetching abstraction** using React Query via custom hooks (useEvents, useMatches, etc.)
- **Type safety** through comprehensive TypeScript interfaces for all data models
- **API route organization** following RESTful principles with dynamic route segments

### System Relationships

The system follows a layered architecture where UI components interact with custom hooks that manage data fetching and state, which in turn communicate with API routes that handle business logic and database operations.

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[UI Components] --> B[Custom Hooks]
    B --> C[API Routes]
    C --> D[Prisma Client]
    D --> E[PostgreSQL Database]
    F[Authentication] --> C
    G[Configuration] --> C
```

### Data Flow

The data flow follows a unidirectional pattern from database to UI, with mutations flowing in the opposite direction:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[(Database)] -->|Prisma| B[API Routes]
    B -->|JSON Response| C[React Query]
    C -->|Data| D[Custom Hooks]
    D -->|Props| E[UI Components]
    F[User Input] -->|Mutation| G[API Routes]
    G -->|Prisma| A
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `app/page.tsx`: Application homepage and entry point
- `app/layout.tsx`: Root layout with shared UI elements
- `app/api/`: API routes for server-side operations

### Core Modules
- **Authentication**: Implemented with Better Auth and protected routes
- **Event Management**: Comprehensive event lifecycle from creation to completion
- **Match System**: Real-time match tracking with scoring and timer functionality
- **Tournament Management**: Bracket generation and tournament progression
- **Rankings**: Championship standings calculation and persistence

### Configuration Approach
- `next.config.ts`: Next.js configuration
- `prisma/schema.prisma`: Database schema definition
- `src/lib/`: Centralized configuration for API, auth, and utilities
- Environment variables for runtime configuration

### External Dependencies
- **Framework**: Next.js 15 with React 19
- **Database**: Prisma ORM with PostgreSQL
- **Authentication**: Better Auth
- **State Management**: React Query for data fetching
- **UI Components**: Radix UI with Tailwind CSS
- **Styling**: Tailwind CSS with custom configuration

### Integration Points
- **API Routes**: RESTful endpoints in `app/api/` directory
- **Database**: Prisma client integration in `src/lib/prisma.ts`
- **Authentication**: Better Auth integration across application
- **Real-time Features**: Live match tracking via token-based access

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Frontend] --> B[API Routes]
    B --> C[Prisma Client]
    C --> D[Database]
    E[Authentication] --> B
    F[External Services] --> B
    G[Static Assets] --> A
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview

BigMatch offers a comprehensive suite of features for sports event management:

1. **User Authentication and Role Management**
   - Multiple user roles (Organizer, Team, Player)
   - Secure authentication flow
   - Role-based access control

2. **Event Lifecycle Management**
   - Event creation and configuration
   - Registration management
   - Status progression through defined states

3. **Tournament Organization**
   - Support for championship and cup formats
   - Automatic bracket generation
   - Draw management

4. **Match Operations**
   - Real-time score updates
   - Match timer with start/pause/reset controls
   - Live match viewing via token access

5. **Rankings and Statistics**
   - Automatic ranking calculation for championships
   - Team performance statistics
   - Historical data tracking

### Implementation Highlights

The application implements a sophisticated type system that ensures data consistency across the stack. The Prisma schema defines the data model, which is then used to generate TypeScript types that are consumed throughout the application.

Authentication is handled through a combination of Better Auth and custom middleware components that protect routes based on user roles and event ownership. The role-based access system uses Higher-Order Components like `RoleGuard` and `EventGuard` to restrict access to specific pages and functionality.

The tournament management system supports both round-robin championships and knockout tournaments, with different rule sets and progression mechanics. The draw system automatically generates brackets based on the number of participating teams.

Real-time match features are implemented through API endpoints that update match state and broadcast changes to connected clients. The scoring system includes configurable rules for different sports and automatic match completion based on predefined conditions.

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> EventCreation: Create Event
    EventCreation --> RegistrationOpen: Open Registration
    RegistrationOpen --> RegistrationClosed: Close Registration
    RegistrationClosed --> InProgress: Start Event
    InProgress --> MatchScheduled: Schedule Match
    MatchScheduled --> MatchLive: Start Match
    MatchLive --> MatchCompleted: Complete Match
    MatchCompleted --> InProgress: Next Match
    InProgress --> Completed: All Matches Complete
    Completed --> [*]
    Error --> Idle: Reset
```

Sources:
- [package.json](package.json)
- [next.config.ts](next.config.ts)
- [prisma/seed.ts](prisma/seed.ts)
- [src/lib/prisma.ts](src/lib/prisma.ts)
- [src/types/event.ts](src/types/event.ts)
- [src/types/match.ts](src/types/match.ts)
- [src/types/tournament.ts](src/types/tournament.ts)
- [src/types/ranking.ts](src/types/ranking.ts)
</blog>
